text:
Introducing ggplot

R graphics vs ggplot

R graphics

hist(exam_data$MATHS)










ggplot2

ggplot(data=exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +

                 boundary = 100,
                 color="black",

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
1.5 ggplot2: data and aesthetic mappings

Data only

ggplot(data = exam_data)










Add aesthetic mapping (x = MATHS)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS))

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
1.7 Geometric objects (geom)

1.7.1 Bar chart: geom_bar()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "darkorange") +
  labs(title = "Number of Pupils by Race",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.2 Dot plot: geom_dotplot()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5,
               fill    = "steelblue",
               colour  = "white") +
  labs(title = "Dot Plot of Maths Scores",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = NULL) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL, breaks = NULL) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.











1.7.3 Histogram: geom_histogram()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins  = 30,
                 colour = "white",
                 fill   = "royalblue") +
  labs(title = "Histogram of Maths Scores",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.4 Modify geom: change bins and colours

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins  = 20,
                 colour = "black",
                 fill   = "lightblue") +
  labs(title = "Histogram of Maths Scores (20 bins)",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.5 Modify aes: fill by gender

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins  = 20,
                 colour = "grey30",
                 alpha  = 0.7,
                 position = "identity") +
  labs(title = "Histogram of Maths Scores by Gender",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Count",
       fill = "Gender") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.6 Density plot: geom_density()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_density(fill = "skyblue",
               alpha = 0.6,
               colour = "navy") +
  labs(title = "Density Plot of Maths Scores",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Density") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)








Density by gender

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           colour = GENDER,
           fill   = GENDER)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.4) +
  labs(title = "Density Plot of Maths Scores by Gender",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Density",
       colour = "Gender",
       fill   = "Gender") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.7 Boxplot: geom_boxplot()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +
  labs(title = "Maths Scores by Gender",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)








Notched boxplot

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch = TRUE,
               fill  = "lightgreen") +
  labs(title = "Notched Boxplot of Maths Scores by Gender",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.8 Violin plot: geom_violin()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS,
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_violin(alpha = 0.6,
              colour = "grey30") +
  labs(title = "Violin Plot of Maths Scores by Gender",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.9 Scatterplot: geom_point()

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(colour = "steelblue",
             alpha  = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Maths vs English Scores",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "English score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










1.7.10 Combine geoms: boxplot + points

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.shape = NA,
               fill = "white") +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.15),
             alpha    = 0.5,
             colour   = "steelblue",
             size     = 1) +
  labs(title = "Maths Scores by Gender (Boxplot + Points)",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
1.8 Stat layers

Boxplot with mean (stat_summary)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom  = "point",
               fun   = "mean",
               colour = "red",
               size   = 3) +
  labs(title = "Maths Scores by Gender with Mean Point",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










Boxplot with mean (geom_point + stat = “summary”)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = GENDER,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat  = "summary",
             fun   = "mean",
             colour = "red",
             size   = 3) +
  labs(title = "Maths Scores by Gender with Mean Point (geom_point)",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Maths score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










Best-fit curve on scatterplot

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7,
             colour = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(size   = 0.7,
              colour = "darkred",
              fill   = "pink",
              alpha  = 0.3) +
  labs(title = "Maths vs English with Smoothed Curve",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "English score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'









Linear model fit

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7,
             colour = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method   = "lm",
              linewidth = 0.7,
              colour   = "darkgreen",
              fill     = "lightgreen",
              alpha    = 0.3) +
  labs(title = "Maths vs English with Linear Fit",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "English score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

1.9.1 facet_wrap()

       aes(x = MATHS)) +

  geom_histogram(bins  = 20,
                 fill  = "darkorange",
                 colour = "white") +

       x = "Maths score",
       y = "Count") +

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
1.10 Coordinates

Vertical bar chart

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Number of Pupils by Race",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










Horizontal bar chart (coord_flip())

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Number of Pupils by Race (Horizontal)",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)










Fix x/y range (coord_cartesian())

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS,
           y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7,
             colour = "steelblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm",
              size   = 0.5,
              colour = "darkred") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100),
                  ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  labs(title = "Maths vs English (0–100 Scale)",
       x = "Maths score",
       y = "English score") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

text:
R graphics vs ggplot
First, let us compare how R Graphics, the core graphical functions of Base R and ggplot plot a simple histogram.

R graphicsggplot2



hist(exam_data$MATHS)











ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10,
                 boundary = 100,
                 colour = "black",
                 fill = "grey") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")











As you can see that the code chunk is relatively simple if R Graphics is used.

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
Plotting a Bar chart

       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
Plotting a Dot plot
In a dot plot, the width of a dot corresponds to the bin width (or maximum width, depending on the binning algorithm), and dots are stacked, with each dot representing one observation.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.









The scale_y_continuous() is used to turn off the y-axis, and binwidth argument is used to change the binwidth to 2.5.

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth=2.5,         
               dotsize = 0.5) +      
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,           
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Hands-on-ex1
section: Adding a best fit curve on a scatter plot
text:
Adding a best fit curve on a scatter plot
The scatterplot below shows the relationship of Maths and English grades of pupils. The interpretability of this graph can be improved by adding a best fit curve.In the code chunk below, geom_smooth() is used to plot a best fit curve on the scatterplot.

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(y= ENGLISH, x= MATHS)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(linewidth=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'









The default smoothing method is loess. The default smoothing method can be overridden as shown below.

ggplot(data= exam_data,
       aes(y= ENGLISH, x= MATHS)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method= lm,
              linewidth= 0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
Working with facet_wrap()
facet_wrap wraps a 1d sequence of panels into 2d. This is generally a better use of screen space than facet_grid because most displays are roughly rectangular. The code chunk below plots a trellis plot using facet-wrap().

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) +
  facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on-ex1
text:
Working with facet_grid()
facet_grid() forms a matrix of panels defined by row and column facetting variables. It is most useful when you have two discrete variables, and all combinations of the variables exist in the data. The code chunk below plots a trellis plot using facet_grid().

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 25) + 
  facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on-ex1
section: Changing the x and y-axis range
text:
Changing the x and y-axis range
The scatter plot below is slightly misleading because the y-axis and x-axis range are not equal.

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









The code chunk below fixed both the y-axis and x-axis range from 0-100.

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth=0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100),
                  ylim = c(0, 100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
